title: Mick's gift
subject_group: Economics, Philosophy, Politics, Religion & Sociology/Family - Social aspects
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Mothers and daughters
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Fathers and daughters
Family, Gender Identity, Relationships & Sexuality/Children - Family relationships
description: Episode of Series "Family foibles". Part of the "Family foibles" series of five documentaries about Australian families. Filmmaker Celeste Geer takes as her starting point a box of long forgotten 16mm amateur film shot by her late grandfather Mick in the 1940s and 1950s, in an attempt to better understand the character of the man she idolised as a child. She found that the memories captured in the footage of his family, friends and travels and the those that emerged through the recollections of family members and an old mate, offered up contradictory images of her grandfather which challenged the mythology around him built up in her family history. A film that questions the way family memories get tailored for the consumption of future generations. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf
